title: Kinetic friction - stopping a spinning wheel

content.description: A solid disk of mass <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math> and radius <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> is spinning with angular speed <math alttext="omega sub 0" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> about an axis perpendicular to its center. The rotational inertia of this disk is <math alttext="I equals, one half times M R squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>I</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>M</mi><msup><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mstyle></math>. A brake is pressed against the edge of the spinning disk with a force of magnitude <math alttext="F" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math> directed toward the center of the disk. The friction between the disk and the brake slows the rotation of the disk, which comes to a stop in two full rotations.
content.question: What is the coefficient of kinetic friction between the brake and the spinning disk?
